bibl.title: Chin Hing v. United States of America. Petitioner's bond pending decision upon said application
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

msIdentifier.repository: National Archives and Records Administration, Seattle Branch, Washington
msIdentifier.collection: RG 21 US District Court Western Division of Washington, Seattle

div1.p: In the United States District Court, in and for the Western District of Washington, Northern Division.
In The Matter of the Aplication of Ching Hing, for a Writ of Habeas Corpus.
No. 28752857 Petitioner's bond pending decision upon said application.

Know all men by these presents, that we, Ching Hing, as principal, and the National Surety Company, a corporation, as Sureties, are held and firmly bound unto the United States of America, in the penal sum of Fifteen Hundred (1500) Dollars for the payment whereof, well and truly to be made in good and lawful money of the United States of America, we do bind ourselves, and each of our heirs, executors, administrators and assigns, jointly and severally, firmly by these presents.
Sealed with our seals and dated this 2nd day of March, 1915.

The condition of the above obligation is such that where heretofore, the above named principal, Ching Hing, duly filed his petition for the allowance of a Writ of Habeas Corpus, and thereupon such Writ issued to Henry M. White, United States Commissioner of Immigration, and the United States Chinese Inspector, Henty Monroe, directed, and thereupon the said Henry M. White, made full return to said petition and upon hearing of said petition on October 16, 1914, a motion was made for continuance for the reason that it was necessary for the petitioner to have certain Interrogatories answered in the City of Washington, D.C., by Lewis F. Post, assistant Secretary of the Department of Labor, and Corry M. Stadden, an attourney of Washington, D.C., and whereupon his Hon. Judge Neterer, one of the judges in the above entitled Court, granted thesaid continuance until such time as such interrogatories were answered, and issued a commission to Thomas G. Lewis, an attorney and notary public
at Washington, D.C., to take the deposition and testimony of said witnesses, and whereupon the said Lewis F. Post, Assistant Secretary of the Department of Labor, has refused to answer certain interrogatories propounded by said petitioner through his attorney, making it necessary for the said petitioner through his attorney to make application in the United States District Court, in the District of Columbia, to compell Lewis F. Post to answer certain interrogatories of this matter and in relation thereto, and that this motion is still pending and further that the hearing upon this petition for Writ of Habeas Corpus, can not be heard until the determination of this matter now pending in the District Court of Washington, D. C.

Now, therefore, if the said Ching Hing shall appear, answer to and abide any Judgment or Order made in said matter, by the United States District Court in and for the Western District of Washington, Northern Division, and shall render himself up in obedience to any Judgement or Order of said District Court, in and for the Western District of Washington, in said matter, then this obligation to be null and void, otherwise to be and remain of full force and virtue.
In witness whereof we have hereunto set our hands and seals the day and year first above written.
Ching Hing By His Atty John J. Sullivan National Surety Company
By George W. Allen Attorney in Fact
Signed, sealed, and delivered in the presence of John J. Sullivan

p.add: Approved Edward E Cushman US Dist Judge
